After birth of son holy person loses miraculous power.
House and family appear overnight to afford hospitality to benighted priests.
Severed head of saint speaks so that searchers can find it.
Stone turns red when saint's picture is removed.
Conversation of animals reveals to man how to become saint.

r: *Encyc. Rel. Ethics Index 26b; Irish: *Cross, O'Suilleabhain 107, Beal XXI 334; German: Grimm No. 3.
Spanish Exempla: Keller; Icelandic: Boberg; Jewish: *Neuman.

d: Angel appears to woman to warn her not to force girl into marriage.
Angel in the form of an old man.

r: English: Wells 76 (Joseph of Aramathie); Italian Novella: Rotunda.

d: Angels appear and help boy prince slay treacherous uncle.
Angel shows saint where to dig for water.
Angel reveals location of lost (buried) object.
Angel brings cross as gift to saint.
Angel helps Peter to escape from prison.

r: *Chauvin VI 184 No. 349; *Fb "engel" I 250; Jewish: *Neuman, bin Gorion Born Judas I 313f., 149f., 371ff., 380.

d: Angel of death spares mother who is suckling children.
r: Type 795*; Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 795*; Russian: Andrejev No. 795A*; Estonian: Aarne FFC XXV No. 795*.
a: As punishment angel must serve as sexton.

r: *Chauvin VI 106 No. 270; *Loomis White Magic 53; Irish myth: *Cross.

d: Angels sing in honor of saint.
Angel choir responds when saint receives orders.
Angels sing on night of Christ's Nativity.

r: Irish: Plummer clxxxii, *Cross; Icelandic: *Boberg; Swiss: Jegerlehner Oberwallis 301 No. 16; Spanish: Keller Espinosa Jr.

d: Mortals visited by angel in vision.
Angel announces birth of Christ to shepherds.
Angel bars abbot from his cell because abbot has cast out a sinning monk.
Angel bars the way to Baalam's ass.
Angels melt snow around saintly babe.
Service of angels marks saint's destination.
Air above grave of converted druid full of angels.
Angels shed light upon saint's tomb.
Angels set heavenly veil upon head of pious woman.
Holy place (object) glorified by angel's presence.
Train of angels rises from graveyard.
Angel passes daily over blessed stone.
Angels appear above grave of fallen girl through virtue of prayers said by her lover (young monk).
Angel beseeches at unholy grave of redeemed sinner until body is moved to sanctified ground.
Angel scourges mortal for disobedience to God.
Angel leaves letter (book) with instructions for saint.
Angel tells saint where to build his church.
Angel informs saint of coming of guests.
Hebrew the language of the angels.

r: **Crane Liber de Miraculis; *DeVooys Middelnederlandse Legenden en Exempelen 57; Genthe Die Jungfrau Maria: ihre Evangelien und ihre Wunder (Halle, 1852); *Encyc. Rel. Ethics Index 366c. Irish: *Cross, O'Suilleabhain 59, 78, Beal XXI 307, 314, 323, 327; Spanish: Keller, Espinosa Jr.

d: Irish saint as "Mary of the Gael".
Virgin Mary prevents (retards) death so as to save sinner's soul.
r: (Sometimes resuscitation.) Alphabet No. 464; Ward II 606 No. 14, 633 No. 31, 650 No. 1; *Crane Miraculis Nos. 6, 7, 10, 31, 39; Wells 169 (De Miraculo Beate Marie); Scala Celi 123a, 125b Nos. 674, 681. Spanish Exempla: Keller.
a: Permits time for repentance and absolution.

d: Virgin Mary brings man back to life after he has seen hell's torments.

r: Alphabet No. 381; Wesselski Mtsnchslatein 78 No. 68; *Crane Miraculis No. 34; Icelandic: Boberg.

d: Virgin Mary returns borrowed money and reveals cheat.
r: Ward II 638 No. 10; *Crane Miraculis No. 33; Wells 167 (Vernon Miracles).
a: A man borrows money from a Jew with the Virgin as security. Unable to return the money in time, he commits the money to the sea with a prayer to the Virgin. The Jew receives it but claims that the money is not paid. The Virgin reveals the cheat.

d: Virgin Mary saves criminal from fire at stake.
Faithfulness to Virgin Mary, even if not to Christ, rewarded.
Virgin Mary supports robber on gallows because he once said "Ave Maria".
Ship in storm saved because of sailors' "Ave Maria".
r: (Cf. +D2141.1.) *Crane Miraculis No. 28; Ward II 626 No. 9, 640 Nos. 12, 14, 15, *677 No. 12.

a: Because of faithfulness in saying "Aves" the words are found imprinted on the dead man's tongue.

d: Blasphemer paralyzed in all members except tongue which had once said "Ave Maria".
Nun forgets to hail Mary and goes into the world to sin.
Joseph and Mary threaten to leave heaven when the man who has always prayed to them is refused admittance.
Murdered boy still sings "Ave" after his death.
r: **Brown PMLA XXI 486ff.; Ward II 656, 697 and passim; Herbert III 528; Wells Catalogue of Romances 166 (Vernon Miracles).
a: (Chaucer's Prioress's Tale.)
His head calls repeatedly, "Ave Maria".

d: Virgin Mary will not let devil (authorities) take robber noble who daily says "Ave".
Virgin forbids devil to take robber as long as he continues to say two "Aves" daily.
Virgin Mary has dissolute monk buried in consecrated ground: his only mass is that of the Virgin.
r: *Crane Miraculis Nos. 3, 9; Ward II 607 No. 15, 660 No. 29; Scala Celi 116a, 116b Nos. 644, 645; Spanish Exempla: Keller.

d: Devotee of Virgin not buried in consecrated ground has lily issue from mouth so that his grave is made known.
r: Spanish Exempla: Keller; Italian Novella: Rotunda.

d: Virgin gives private mass to devout lady unable to attend.
Miracles of healing performed before image of Virgin Mary.
Virgin Mary restores severed hand to Saint John Damascene.
a: He had cut it off to repress lust.

d: Virgin Mary saves life of man who at devil's instigation has castrated himself.
a: She will not, however, restore his severed members.

d: Virgin Mary restores life to drowned man who always had saluted her.
Virgin Mary designates favorite for election for office.
Virgin restores office to an ignorant man because of his faith.
Virgin pardons man who repented for cheating in election.
Virgin Mary supplies mead for unprepared hostess of the king.
Portrait of the Virgin appears to devotee.
Virgin Mary rescues man attacked by the devil.
r: *Crane Miraculis No. 23; Ward II 612 No. 30; Spanish Exempla: Keller; West Indies: Flowers 580.

d: Virgin Mary brings man a pact he signed with the devil and frees the man from devil's power.
Virgin miraculously prevents nun (monk) from deserting cloister.
r: Ward II 634 No. 34, 636 Nos. 7, 41, 667 No. 13, 721 No. 17; Spanish Exempla: Keller.

d: Image of Virgin tries in vain to keep nun from leaving convent.
r: Crane Vitry 160 No. 60; Spanish Exempla: Keller.

d: Devotee of Virgin is comforted in the hour of death.
Miracles performed under protection of Virgin Mary.
Boy under protection of Virgin Mary pulled from well alive after a week.
Virgin Mary saves devotee from death in waves.
Virgin Mary destroys Moorish army besieging Constantinople.
Virgin Mary saves devotee's son from shipwreck.
Image of Virgin Mary works miracles.

r: Ward II 603 No. 6, 606 No. 12, 610 No. 25, 618 No. 39, 648 No. 44; Spanish Exempla: Keller.

d: Virgin Mary appears to erring man.
Virgin Mary appears to erring monk and exalts him to prayer.
a: His prayers weave her a garment.

d: Virgin Mary appears and pardons monk who has been too overworked to pray to her.
Virgin Mary aids repentant slayer of priest.
a: Priest is resurrected in order to forgive murderer and then is returned to tomb.

d: Virgin Mary appears to devout nun with infant Jesus.
a: The nun devoutly prayed to see Him.

d: Devotee of Virgin Mary given present by her.
Stella Maris: Virgin Mary as protectress of sailors.
r: Canney Revue de l'Histoire des Religions CXV (1937) 90ff.; Krappe Review of Religion (1948) 376ff.

d: During a flood the Virgin descends into the streets to save her image from the flood waters.
Belief in the life to come.
Doctrine of immortality taught by druids.
Man converted to belief in future life on deathbed.
a: Feels sure nevertheless that nothing will come of it.

d: Dying man refuses to believe in life to come.
Given choice between life and heaven, person chooses latter.

r: (Cf. +T510.) *Encyc. Rel. Ethics Index 272a; Spanish Exempla: Keller.

d: Proclamation of dogma of Immaculate Conception stops plague.
Man miraculously dies for opposing dogma of Immaculate Conception.
a: Attempt to disprove the dogma by false miracle. Sham dead man is to rise if the dogma is not true. He is found to be actually dead.

r: Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 779*; Russian: Andrejev No. 841I*.
a: Hermit wants to prove truth of these words of the Gospel and asks for the hand of the princess. Performs the difficult task imposed upon him.

r: *Encyc. Rel. Ethics Index 251b; Irish myth: Cross.

d: Insane man burns heretic in his bed: restored to his senses as reward.

a: Heathen baptized into devil's possession.

d: Baptismal water vanishes before Aryan bishop.
Hero renounces heaven because dead companions (heathen) are not there.
Author of book against heretic honored by Virgin Mary and angels.
Man sets fire to his house and perishes in it rather than accept Christianity.
Conversion from one religion to another.

r: (Cf. +M177.1.) Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 555; Dickson 199 n. 89; Malone PMLA XLIII 413. Irish: *Cross, O'Suilleabhain 65, Beal XXI 325; Icelandic: *Boberg; English: Wells 88 (Roland and Vernagu); Spanish Exempla: Keller; Jewish: *Neuman; Tahiti: Henry Ancient Tahiti (Honolulu, 1928) 178.

d: Three (two) Irishmen who believed in Christianity before the coming of St. Patrick.

r: Dickson 193 98 passim; Alphabet No. 558; Icelandic: *Boberg; Irish: *Cross, O'Suilleabhain 71, 74, Beal XXI 326; English: Wells 91 (Otuel), 119 (Octovian), *Hibbard 45ff.; Italian Novella: *Rotunda.

d: Conversion to Christianity by miracle of seeing blood flow from Jesus' image.
Conversion to Christianity through appearance of the cross and angels.
Conversion to Christianity because the heathen gods prove to be less powerful.
Conversion because saint's staff miraculously goes through neophytes' foot.
Conversion to Christianity on pain of death.
Miraculous beautification upon conversion to Christianity.
Conversion to Christianity out of gratitude.
a: Ruler has captive baptize his sister and then marry her. Grateful for past kindnesses.

d: Saladin asks to be made a Christian knight.
Swans (transformed children) do not suffer in harsh weather after conversion to Christianity.
Conversion to Christianity because of admiration for Christian virtue.
Conversion to Christianity through show of forgiveness and gentleness.

r: Irish myth: *Cross; Icelandic: *Boberg; Jewish: Neuman; India: Thompson-Balys.

d: Pagan sybil draws picture of Madonna and Child in sand.
a: Result of vision.

d: Jews protesting against marriage of Jewess and Christian are struck dumb.
Temple about to be taken over by pagans saved by appearance of a Sign of the Cross (image of the Virgin).
Dove flies out of man's mouth.
r: Italian Novella: Rotunda; Spanish Exempla: Keller.
a: Impious anchorite has agreed to forsake his religion in return for the possession of a maid. When he repents the dove reenters his mouth.

d: Idols found on their faces after saint's arrival.
Duel (debate) to prove which religion is better.
Wise heretic is vanquished in debate with a Christian.
Brahmin wins a discussion on religion.
Magician overpowered in contest with a saint.
Contest of St. Peter with Simon Magus, a magician.
Prayer-contest to prove which religion is better.
Contest of miraculous powers between a Yogi and a Musselman.
Pagan disputant with Christian stricken dumb.
r: English: Wells 76 (Joseph of Aramathie); Spanish Exempla: Keller.

d: Pagan disputant with Christian bested by the words put in his mouth by God.
Life of heroic age preferable to Christian living.
Buddhists become slaves of Taoists because they cannot produce rain.
Saint dispels pagan devils from ancient shrines.
Pagan shrines and idols, or magic books destroyed by fire from heaven.
Heathen idols sink into earth up to their necks through power of saint.
Saint's bachall pointed at idol defaces it.
Christian and Jewish traditions about each other.
Christian child killed to furnish blood for Jewish rite.
r: (Cf. +V254.7.) **V. Manzini La superstizione omicida e i sacrifici umani, con particolare riguardo alle accuse contro gli Ebrei (2d ed., Padua, 1930); **Berger Milusine VIII 169ff.; *Ward II 656 No. 3; *Brown PMLA XXI 486ff. English: Child III 240ff., IV 497a.
a: (Hugh of Lincoln.)

r: German: H. Rauchfuss Alte Geschichte u. neue Sagen aus Thuringen 60.

d: Jewish child thrown into oven by father for taking eucharist.
r: *Ward II 601; Irish myth: Cross (+V35.1.0.1); Spanish Exempla: Keller.
a: Preserved by Virgin Mary.

d: Jewish child resurrected (saved by power of Virgin Mary) after being burned to ashes for eating consecrated bread in Christian church.
A Christianized Jew becomes a priest.
r: Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 3270, Legends Nos. 416ff.
a: During Mass, he stabs the consecrated host, blood flows (cf. +C55, +J1261.2, +V30). He kills the other priest who saw him commit the sacrilege, and before killing, forces him to renounce his faith. A miracle exposes the murderer.

d: Heathen beats his god because of misfortune.
Doctor ridicules belief in Devil, Heaven, and Hell.
Prolonged prostration in worship causes death.
Hindu drinks water by mistake from Mohammedan's vessel: his fortune turns to evil.
Romans won't include Jesus in their pantheon because of his poverty which they hate.

r: *Encyc. Rel. Ethics Index 111c; Spanish Exempla: Keller; Jewish: *Neuman.
Irish: O'Suilleabhain 22, Beal XXI 307, 337; Spanish: Espinosa Jr.

d: Charity rewarded above prayer or hearing of masses.
r: Irish: O'Suilleabhain 131; Spanish: Boggs FFC XC 87 No. 756E*.

d: Queen gives away a sleeve of her dress: miraculously restored.
Saint exchanges coat with beggar: gold sleeves miraculously appear.
Man who has given all in charity has foot amputated: restored miraculously.
Stones turn to gold for charitable money-lender.
a: Hence money borrowed for wedding is never refused by lenders.

d: Treasure given away by saint miraculously restored.
Man earns as much as he gave away for charity in his former life.
Food given away by saint miraculously restored.
Charitable king blows nose after having given to beggar.
a: Huge ruby appears in his kerchief.

d: Jesus appears to St. Martin when he gives his cloak to beggar.
Charity miraculously repaid: flame settles on forehead.
Miraculous manifestations during act of charity.
Bread stolen by St. Nicholas for purpose of feeding poor is miraculously restored.
The more bread (flour) the monks give to the poor the more God places in their bins.
Son's acts of charity save his father's soul.
Saint shares punishment of sinful man whose cloak he shared in life.
Children envious of money given by deceased father to bishop.
a: In vision they take their father's body up and find a quittance saying that he has received more than a hundredfold reward.

d: Man convicted of cheating at his bookkeeping is excused when it is learned that he has given the money to the poor.
Shipman refuses alms: ship turned to stone.
Uncharitable knight drives bargain even in giving alms: devoured by serpents.
a: His alms of corn turn to serpents.

r: Alphabet Nos. 260, 754, 786, 789, 792; Irish: Beal XXI 337; Spanish: Espinosa Jr.

d: Conqueror restores kingship to king for charity.
Pious man charitable to man who has formerly refused him charity.
Mendicant refuses to accept alms from barren woman.
Saint repeatedly bestows father's goods upon the poor.
Merit for charity lost by asking work in return.

r: *Encyc. Rel. Ethics Index 384a, 389b; Irish myth: Cross.

d: First-born son and one of every ten born thereafter given to Church.
Obedient and industrious nun the worthiest in the convent.
r: Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 690; Alphabet No. 322; Spanish Exempla: Keller.

d: Truthful monk refuses to cheat even for his order.
Monk lives where people speak ill of him to avoid danger of flattery.

a: Man captured by robbers is so confident that God will protect him that he is saved.

r: *Loomis White Magic 111f.; *Encyc. Rel. Ethics Index 42b; Irish myth: *Cross; Spanish Exempla: Keller; Jewish: *Neuman; India: *Thompson-Balys.

d: Kingship renounced to become an ascetic.
Since salvation is predestined, asceticism deemed useless.
Husband abandons wife to become ascetic.

r: Alphabet Nos. 709, 711, 712, 725; Swiss: Jegerlehner Oberwallis 310 No. 32; Spanish Exempla: Keller.
Alphabet Nos. 24, 145; Wesselski Mtsnchslatein 170 No. 135; Irish myth: *Cross; India: *Thompson-Balys.

d: Ascetic faster increases his sufferings by placing food and drink before himself.
r: Alphabet Nos. 22, 23; Scala Celi 4a No. 16; India: Thompson-Balys.

d: Saint refuses pearls as alms and asks for food.

a: Cleric stands with hands extended in shape of cross.

d: Saint always extends one hand toward heaven while performing such acts as eating or reaping.
Ascetic cleric prays to become diseased.
Saint never wears woolen clothing, but skins of wolves and other beasts.
Ascetic cleric sleeps (prays) with wet sheet (mantle) about him.
Saint stands for seven years without sleep.
Ascetic cleric avoids listening to music.
Saint confines himself in narrow pen during Lent.
Saint stands (asleep) while bird builds nest and hatches brood in his hand.
Ascetic cleric lives for seven years on whale's back.
Ascetic cleric renounces world (to become a herder).
Monk refuses chance of having temptation removed since he considers it strengthening to have it ever present to test him.
Evil ascetic misuses magic powers obtained through religious meditation.
Boy takes twelve years to wash off ascetic's dirt.
Cleric surrenders life that body may consecrate land.

r: *Encyc. Rel. Ethics Index 113b, 136c; West Indies: Flowers 580.

d: Monk seduces girl; then kills her; becomes infidel.
Nun hidden by abbess from pursuing knight betrays her own hiding place to him.
a: Is afterwards abandoned.

d: Nun tempted into sinning with man who tells her God can't see things that happen in the dark.
Priest uses cook-book instead of breviary.
Priest is bribed into betraying the confessional.
Clerical vows because of disappointment in love.
Man becomes hermit when he realizes selfishness of his beloved's love.
Former monk refuses to take pay for his work, considering it as a religious act.
Monk who has left order punished (dies in torment).
Monk who has left his order forgiven and miraculously reinstated.
Man who is disappointed with his religious order renounces his vow.
Saint leaves his order because he is fond of music.
Anchorite tempted by money to return to worldly life.

r: *Encyc. Rel. Ethics Index 632b; Irish myth: *Cross; Jewish: *Neuman.

d: God speaks in vision to devotee.
Only man without sin can see God.

r: **Becker Medieval Visions of Heaven and Hell (Baltimore, 1899); **Ward II 396ff. Irish: *Cross, O'Suilleabhain 57, Beal XXI 322; English: Malory Morte D'Arthur XV 3; Finnish-Swedish: Wessman 105 No. 932; Spanish Exempla: Keller; Jewish: *Neuman.

d: Vision of angels defending road to heaven against devils.

r: *Becker (see +V511.1); Alphabet No. 610; Dickson 265; Herbert III 25; **Ward II 386ff.; *Crane Vitry 260f. Irish myth: *Cross; Icelandic: *Boberg; Spanish Exempla: Keller.

d: Girl sees vision of her mother in hell.
a: She chooses to live the poor life of her father which leads to heaven.

d: Visions of Land of the Saints.

a: Man sees his own soul being judged.
A clerk sees his good and evil deeds being weighed. He asks them to throw his faith in Christ (the Virgin) into the scale. He is saved.

d: Man whose only good deed was unintentional sees this deed outweigh all his evil in the scales of judgment.
Vision of the earth in the devil's snares.
a: Saint sees earth in snares.
Chairs of gold, silver, crystal (glass) assigned to saints according to merit.

d: Wife sees moon enter mouth of husband; husband sees star enter mouth of wife: famous child (saint) will be born.
Saint sees vision of flames covering Ireland quenched except for sparks; then great light appears, dispelling darkness.
a: Flames are those of the faith brought by St. Patrick; they become less until restored by St. Columkill.

d: When shower falls, small stone becomes larger, large stone wastes away.
a: Vision of present and future state of Irish church.

d: Vision in which swineherd sees yew tree upon a rock, with an oratory in front of it and angels ascending from it.
a: Vision interpreted by druid as symbolizing founding of Cashel and the royal line of Munster.

d: Vision in which chieftain sees pair of gray seals that sucked at his two breasts.
a: They are two of his allies who are being overpowered by invaders.

d: Vision in which king sees whelp reared by him gather dogs of Ireland and Britain against him but suffer death in battle at last.
a: The whelp is one of king's two foster sons.

d: Vision in which saint foresees allegorically the ramifications of king's family Irish myth: Cross.
Vision in which king sees his four sons changed into lion, greyhound, beagle, cur, which fight with alternating success, until lion subdues the other three.

r: *Encyc. Rel. Ethics Index 517b; Irish myth: Cross.

d: Sinner reformed after visit to heaven and hell.
The only king ever saved in spite of himself.
Sinner who thinks of God saved; devotee who thinks of worldly things goes to hell.
Worship of particular deity brings reward of birth in Brahma-world.
Pilgrimage to follow roads Christ walked.
Intervention of Providence saves person's life.
Man is prevented from taking passage on ship which later sinks.
Man hears voice telling him to leave danger spot in mine.
